words: Madagascar.&nbsp ; An island off the coast of Africa.&nbsp ; It ’s one of the most biologically
diverse places in the world . Almost all of its plants and animals are n’t found anywhere
else on Earth. &nbsp ; And when we looked at it from space , we saw a spot . A
massive dark circle , almost perfectly round , over thirteen kilometers in diameter , and
big enough that roads are diverted on either side of it.&nbsp ; Looking at it from the
side , we could see it was a mountain . And if you zoomed all the way in , you could
see a village nestled in the crater at its center.&nbsp ; 8 kilometers from
the closest labeled town on Google Maps.&nbsp ; Isolated in a remote part of a remote
region of a geographically isolated country.&nbsp ; It looked like it could have been
there for generations . But if you looked backward through time … & nbsp ; … each year … & nbsp ; … it gets
smaller and smaller … & nbsp ; … and before 2008 , there was no
one there at all . I wanted to try to answer one question : Why did
these people move to such an incredibly
isolated place ? I was really starting from
zero here.&nbsp ; I did n't know anyone in Madagascar . I did n't know that much about

there was a video . Geotagged right next to the village on top of the mountain.&nbsp ;
But , then …  &nbsp ; It was just more Attack on Titan
stuff . Also written in Russian. &nbsp ; After a while , it felt like the internet alone was not going to

Tsilavo is talking about this moment , right here . When India broke
apart from Madagascar.&nbsp ; Because these rocks are 90 million years old,&nbsp ; it makes sense that the
volcano might have something to do with this massive separation of continents.&nbsp ; So we
went looking for experts who knew more about the breakup of Madagascar and India.&nbsp ;
And we found Joe Meert . A geology professor who ’s written a bunch about the
movement and formation of continents.&nbsp ; This was a real crash course on volcanic geology , so I
asked our motion designer Matt to help me make this a little bit easier to follow .
Madagascar and India happened to be located beneath this really deep -
seated mantle source , they 're called plumes. &nbsp ; When that plume reaches the planet ’s crust ,
it forms a hot spot . As Madagascar moved over the hotspot , it burned a hole through
Madagascar and produced all the volcanics all over the island . As Madagascar ’s
continental plate continued to move , those volcanoes were eventually cut off from the
hotspot.&nbsp ; And without a heat source , they cooled and collapsed . And then you 're left with the plumbing system that
was underneath that volcano. &nbsp ; So that ’s what we were looking at : the collapsed
remnants of a volcano formed by a hotspot that had broken up apart Madagascar and
India. &nbsp ; At this point , I had no idea what any of this might have to do with the village we could see on Google
Earth . But right about then , we heard back from another Malagasy expert we ’d
emailed . He sent us a link to mindat.org — this is like the Wikipedia of minerals and
mines ... … and it had a page about the mountain.&nbsp ; The Ambohiby
Massif.&nbsp ; Finally . We knew the name of this
mountain that had been unlabeled on every other map we ’d seen so far.&nbsp ; And we could search for
it.&nbsp ; We found maps from 1899 , 1903 , and 1916 ,
where the Ambohiby was always labeled as a lush forest … … the only one for
almost 100 kilometers . That definitely did n’t seem to be the case anymore . But maybe these
old trees were a clue . We kept looking.&nbsp ; And we found old reports . One
from 1933 said that at the “ highest part of the massif there is a very open
valley , called by the indigenous Andranomangatsiaka , or " where we find fresh
water . " Water.&nbsp ; Maybe that 's why the
villagers chose to move there . The mountain ’s higher elevation meant it got more moisture , feeding these streams that
flowed down the mountain in every direction … &nbsp ; and making the center a
perfect place for a village to thrive.&nbsp ; Then we tried to find
reports that were a little bit more recent . And on Google Scholar , we found a 2012 paper about
the origins of the Ambohiby.&nbsp ; It covered everything from the geochemistry , to plate
tectonics , to microscopic images of its rocks . And it included rock samples
taken right next to the crater village . The paper was written by a South African geoscientist named
Ndivhuwo Cecilia Mukosi.&nbsp ; And if she took rock samples from right here , when the village
already looked like this , she had to have been in contact with the people living there.&nbsp ; Mukosi was busy doing
field research for the next few days. &nbsp ; So in the meantime , we dug deeper into her paper . And it
told us what the formation actually was . An alkaline ring
complex.&nbsp ; Alkaline refers to the chemistry of the magma.&nbsp ; It ’s the kind of molten rock that appears when
continents break apart , like Madagascar and India did 90 million years ago.&nbsp ; I took
this new term , and looked at dozens more across the world .
In Sudan , Egypt , Niger , Russia , Namibia ,
Zimbabwe , The United States . They were everywhere.&nbsp ; A whole planet
covered in circles.&nbsp ; The remnants of long extinct volcanoes .
I wanted to talk to someone who could tell me why a community of people would want to live
on top of an alkaline ring complex.&nbsp ; So I went looking for the most famous researcher of the most
famous alkaline ring complex out there . That ’s when this caught my
eye.&nbsp ; The Richat Structure. &nbsp ; Also called the Eye
of the Sahara.&nbsp ; It ’s an alkaline ring complex in Mauritania surrounded by conspiracy

that “ nobody knows what it is!”&nbsp ; But geologist Michel Jébrak does know
what it is . He ’s done tons of research there , and even helped get an illustration of it onto Mauritania ’s
currency .
Soil.&nbsp ; Maybe that was why they moved here . This alkaline ring complex , formed when continents broke
apart , left behind a valley with remarkably fertile soil.&nbsp ;

More specifically , they migrated from
Manandriana , a district in the region of Amoron’i Mania , in the central highlands of
Madagascar.&nbsp ; A journey of over 380 kilometers. &nbsp ; Like the majority
of people in Amoron’i Mania , the Ambohiby residents are Betsileo.&nbsp ; The third largest of
Madagascar ’s 18 main ethnic groups . Meaning they did n't just migrate to a new home – & nbsp ; they
also became an ethnic minority.&nbsp ; Now living in a place where the Merina people are
the majority . It still was n’t clear why
they chose this place in particular , somewhere so remote.&nbsp ; Until they
sat down to interview Razafinatiala , one of the village ’s elders .
And they gave it a name.&nbsp ; Anosibe Ambohiby.&nbsp ; Anosibe Ambohiby.&nbsp ;
Anosibe Ambohiby — or " Big Island " Ambohiby.&nbsp ;
So we had an
answer about why they lived here.&nbsp ; And why they had traveled all this way to live in a place like
this.&nbsp ; It was for the water and it was for the soil.&nbsp ; But more than anything
else , it was for space . And it ’s easy to see why.&nbsp ; In the entire
district of Tsiroanomandidy , there are just over 49 people per square kilometer.&nbsp ; But in the migrants ’ original
home of Manadriana , that density is more than twice as high . And for farmers like
them , space to plant , to breed livestock , to build a life is everything .
And then the villagers took Lalie and the crew to see what they ’d done with all
of that space .
A massive field of hundreds of lemon and orange trees.&nbsp ;
The citrus
are a cash crop : fruits grown for the purpose of selling at a market .
But to sell their produce at a market , they have to transport it down the
mountain to Antaniditra . The same difficult journey that Lalie and her team had just done .
Remoteness was the thing that first fascinated us about this village . And it was a central part of
their story.&nbsp ; But it was a story that stretched far beyond this place.&nbsp ; Madagascar has some
of the least developed road networks in the world with just 5 kilometers of road per 100
square kilometers of land.&nbsp ; The majority of Madagascar ’s population lives in
rural areas a lot like this one . But only a tiny fraction of that rural population lives within 2
kilometers of a road that ’s usable all year long.&nbsp ; Which means that almost 16 million
people live essentially unconnected.&nbsp ; Having better , more connected roads means an
easier time accessing schools , hospitals , and markets . An easier time building a better
life.&nbsp ;
